questions.text: Why is CT able to reconstruct a 3D image from multiple 2D X-ray images?

options.B: Because attenuation values can be stacked directly
options.C: Because projections are acquired around an axis of rotation
options.D: Because detectors measure depth information directly

questions.explanation: Slide "CT – Terminology" states: "Generating 3D image of the inside of an object from multiple 2D X-Ray images taken around a single axis of rotation." The rotation provides angular diversity needed for reconstruction.

questions.text: What is the physical meaning of the Beer–Lambert law in CT?

options.A: X-ray intensity decreases linearly with object thickness
options.B: X-ray attenuation is independent of material
options.C: Measured intensity corresponds to an integral of attenuation along a ray

questions.explanation: From slides "X-Ray Attenuation": attenuation in inhomogeneous media is expressed as an "attenuation integral" over the ray path, which is exactly the Beer–Lambert law formulation.

questions.text: Why are logarithms applied to detector intensities before CT reconstruction?

options.B: To convert exponential attenuation into a linear integral

questions.explanation: From the attenuation slides: Beer–Lambert law is exponential in intensity. Taking the logarithm yields a linear path integral of the attenuation coefficient μ, which is required for reconstruction.

questions.text: What does a sinogram represent in CT?

options.B: The Fourier transform of the image
options.C: The Radon transform of the object

questions.explanation: Slides "The Radon Transform – Example" show that the sinogram is obtained by applying the Radon transform, i.e. integrals of the object over straight lines for different angles.

questions.text: Why is the Radon transform fundamental to CT reconstruction?

options.B: Because CT images are stored in Radon space
options.C: Because X-ray measurements correspond to line integrals

questions.explanation: Slide "The Radon Transform in 2D": "Integral of a 2D function over straight lines." This exactly matches the physics of X-ray attenuation measurements.

questions.text: What key insight does the Fourier Slice Theorem provide?

options.B: A projection corresponds to a slice in Fourier space
options.C: CT reconstruction is impossible without interpolation
options.D: Noise is removed in Fourier space

questions.explanation: Slide "The Fourier Slice Theorem": "The 1D Fourier transform of a projection is equivalent to a slice of the 2D Fourier transform of f."

questions.text: Why is direct Fourier inversion impractical in real CT systems?

options.B: The Fourier space is sampled irregularly

questions.explanation: Slides "Direct Fourier Inversion": "Problem: Irregular sampling of Fourier space → interpolation required." This interpolation introduces errors.

questions.text: Why does simple backprojection produce a blurred image?
questions.explanation: Slides "Filtered Backprojection": backprojection causes "amplification of low frequencies," which leads to blurring unless compensated by filtering.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the ramp filter in FBP?
questions.explanation: Slide "Filtered Backprojection": filtering weights projections with respect to frequency "to compensate for amplification of low frequencies by the backprojection."

questions.text: Why are smoothing filters (e.g. Shepp-Logan, Hamming) used instead of a pure ramp filter?
questions.explanation: Slide "Choice of the right filter": "Add smoothing to cope with detector noise." Pure ramp filters amplify noise.

questions.text: What happens when the number of projections is too small?
questions.explanation: Slide "Effect of number of projections": few projections lead to severe streak artifacts due to insufficient angular sampling.

questions.text: Why does spiral CT require z-interpolation when using 2D FBP?
questions.explanation: Slide "Modern CT Scanners": "Circular trajectory required for FBP → z-Interpolation/Filtering to use 2D FBP for spiral CT reconstruction."

questions.text: Why is a designated 3D reconstruction algorithm required for cone-beam CT?
questions.explanation: Slides "3D Cone-beam CT": cone-beam geometry cannot be reconstructed slice-by-slice; hence "Designated 3D reconstruction required!"

questions.text: What is the main limitation of analytical reconstruction methods like FBP?

options.B: They cannot be implemented on GPUs
options.C: They assume simplified physics and geometry

questions.explanation: Slide "Comparison of Reconstruction Techniques": analytical methods have "Restriction to linear transmission" and "other physical effects difficult to incorporate."

questions.text: Why are iterative reconstruction methods advantageous for low-dose CT?

options.A: They remove the need for filtering
options.B: They directly invert the system matrix
options.C: They incorporate noise models and prior knowledge

questions.explanation: Slides "Iterative Reconstruction & Extensions": prior knowledge can be incorporated "to yield improved results for few projections, low dose, truncated data."
